pageContext.title: This Malaysian startup has 12m users worldwide. Here’s how it runs its 58-strong team
pageContext.content:
This week in Tech in Asia Jobs shares insights into how successful companies operate, hire, and more.

Founded in 2012, Piktochart is a visual communication tool for non-designers.

It started out as one of the first do-it-yourself infographic makers in the market. Since then, it has expanded to accommodate different formats for visual storytelling, including infographics, presentations, reports, and posters. The 58-person team now serves over 12 million users worldwide, with most of them coming from the US.

Here’s how Piktochart runs its team at its headquarters in Penang, Malaysia.

A typical day at work

The entrance. / Photo credit: Piktochart

Forty-one employees work in Piktochart’s 15,000 square-foot office in Penang. The rest of the team works remotely. Another office in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia’s capital, is in the works.

The pantry. / Photo credit: Piktochart

Work days at Piktochart begin in the pantry, where everyone can catch up over breakfast. Piktochart has breakfast and lunch catered in for the staff daily.

Core values

Photo credit: Piktochart

Piktochart’s core values are captured in the word “hopeful”: humble, open up, passionate, excellent, fun-loving, user focused, and love.

Meeting spaces

Photo credit: Piktochart

Photo credit: Piktochart

Meeting spaces feature the company’s brand colors on the walls and are designed to let in ample natural light.

Named after Piktochart’s “hopeful” core values, meeting rooms are regularly used for design sprints and team kickoff meetings every Monday morning.

Monday afternoon meetings

Photo credit: Piktochart

Monday afternoon meetings present an opportunity for team members to get up to speed with each other, especially since they’re scattered across the globe. Teams share their metrics and project updates during this meeting.

Remote employees join in via video call, and communicate regularly using tools like Slack and Zoom.

Team retreats are held once a year, where Piktochart flies the entire team to different locations to bond, work, and play under the same roof for a few days. They’ve had these annual gatherings in South Korea, Melbourne, the Maldives, and Bali so far.

Wednesday lunch hours

Photo credit: Piktochart

Every Wednesday, everyone gathers for a special lunch hour that includes a lightning presentation from a team member. The focus could be anything from tips on how to prepare keto diets to personal Ask Me Anything sessions.

The technical team

Photo credit: Piktochart

The technical team is led by co-founder Andrea Zaggia (fourth from left, front), who is responsible for charting the technology roadmap, building and organizing development resources, and delivering the product vision and schedule.

The organization of the product and engineering team is inspired by Spotify’s matrix model. There are UI/UX, frontend, and backend chapters, with each chapter having its own team leader. Squads are cross-functional teams formed with people across these chapters, broken down into units that manage the different aspects of the business, like the core product or Pro subscriptions. Squads report to a product manager. There are also shared resources in chapters such as development operations.

At a user interview

Photo credit: Piktochart

Product managers and researchers conduct regular user interviews to find out how they can best help users achieve their goals with Piktochart. User interviews are held via video calls.

Taking care of the team’s well-being

Photo credit: Piktochart

Piktochart hosts weekly yoga and basketball sessions to ensure employees clock in some time to exercise.

They also promote flexible working arrangements such as “work-from-home Fridays”, where everyone is given the option to do their work from a location of their choice.

The games room

Playing a friendly game of foosball / Photo credit: Piktochart

Staff can take work breaks in the designated games room. There are board games, an electronic dart machine, an Xbox Kinect console, and foosball – the crowd favourite.

The mural

Photo credit: Piktochart

Piktochart is located in Georgetown in Penang, a city famous for its street art. Taking inspiration from that, the startup created its own mural in the office with the help of its designers.

Hiring

Photo credit: Piktochart

Zaggia shares that his favorite part of working at Piktochart is the people.

“We don’t have everything figured out, but we try our very best. At times it might be frustrating,” he says. “At the end of the day, our core values end with ‘love’, and if you are not the type that enjoys growing with others and learning from one another, this will not be the place for you.”
